statement: D. George and Interesting Graphtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutGeorge loves graphs. Most of all, he loves interesting graphs. We will assume that a directed graph isinteresting, if it meets the following criteria:The graph doesn't contain any multiple arcs;There is vertexv(we'll call her thecenter), such that for any vertex of graphu, the graph contains arcs(u,v)and(v,u). Please note that the graph also contains loop(v,v).The outdegree of all vertexes except for thecenterequals two and the indegree of all vertexes except for thecenterequals two. The outdegree of vertexuis the number of arcs that go out ofu, the indegree of vertexuis the number of arcs that go inu. Please note that the graph can contain loops.However, not everything's that simple. George got a directed graph ofnvertices andmarcs as a present. The graph didn't have any multiple arcs. As George loves interesting graphs, he wants to slightly alter the presented graph and transform it into an interesting one. In one alteration he can either remove an arbitrary existing arc from the graph or add an arbitrary arc to the graph.George wonders: what is the minimum number of changes that he needs to obtain an interesting graph from the graph he's got as a present? Help George and find the answer to the question.InputThe first line contains two space-separated integersnandm(2 ≤n≤ 500, 1 ≤m≤ 1000) — the number of vertices and arcs in the presented graph.Each of the nextmlines contains two space-separated integersai,bi(1 ≤ai,bi≤n) — the descriptions of the graph's arcs. You are given a directed graph with $n$ vertices and $m$ edges.  

A graph is considered "interesting" if it meets the following conditions:

* There are no multiple edges between any two vertices.
* There exists a vertex $v$ (the "center") such that for every vertex $u$ in the graph, there are edges $(u,v)$ and $(v,u)$.  Note that the graph may also contain a loop at vertex $v$ (an edge $(v,v)$).
* Every vertex except the center has an outdegree of 2 (two outgoing edges) and an indegree of 2 (two incoming edges).

Determine the minimum number of edges that need to be added or removed from the given graph to make it "interesting".

You are given a directed graph with a certain number of vertices and edges.  The graph needs to be modified to meet these rules:

* No edge can point to the same vertex twice.
* There must be a central vertex where every other vertex has an edge pointing to it and an edge pointing away from it.
* Every vertex except the central vertex must have exactly two incoming edges and two outgoing edges.

Find the minimum number of edges that need to be added or removed to make the graph follow these rules.
